709280f-a.folder: Manhattan : 6th Avenue & Houston Street (West)., Manhattan, NY
709280f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue Extension South, north from West Houston Street. Shown under construction is the new thoroughfare and the subway under same. This incorporated the former Hancock Street. The 6 story tenements at the left are at the bend formed by Cornelia Street. This appears in both Views 1 and 2. View 3 is taken from atop the Graphic Arts Building on Varick Street.
Note the dome atop the new church of the St. Carlos Missionary Fathers. This organization was formerly located where the circular open pit is in the center of View 2. The Sixth Avenue "El" line turns eastward on W. 3rd Street. This structure was taken down in 1938.
View 1: September 1, 1928
View 2: October 11, 1928
View 3: June 23, 1930
P. L. Sperr
709280f-a.title: Manhattan : 6th Avenue - Houston Street (West).

724517f-a.text:
(1) 196 West Houston Street, north side, west of Sixth Avenue and Bedford Street.
June 15, 1930. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same, and showing a further view westward to No. 206.
May 29, 1935. P.L. Sperr.

724517f-b.text:
(1) 196 West Houston Street, north side, west of Sixth Avenue and Bedford Street.

709268f-a.folder: 6th Avenue & Houston Street (West)- King Street., Manhattan, NY
709268f-a.text:
(1) Sixth Ave., (Extension), east side, south from West Houston, to and including King Streets. The two 5-story buildings whose rears are shown, are Nos. 5 and 3 King Street, at, and adjoining the N.E. corner of Sixth Ave. The 5-story house at the extreme right, is No. 4 King Street, and adjoins the S.E. corner of Sixth Ave., there being an empty lot at the corner (not seen).
May 29, 1935. P.L. Sperr.

(2) The same location several years later. West Houston Street is at the left.
April 5, 1939. P.L. Sperr
709268f-a.title: Manhattan: 6th Avenue - Houston Street (West)- King Street.

716653f-a.folder: Bedford Street & Houston Street, Manhattan, NY
716653f-a.text:
(1)
Bedford Street, northwest from Houston Street at Congress (Sixth Avenue Extension). Bedford Street runs northwest, parallel to the third section (originally Herring's Street) of Bleecker Street, to Christopher Street, and, like the corresponding section of Bleecker, lies almost entirely within the old Herring farm. The farm line crosses Bedford Street at Nos. 10 and 17 (about where two cars are parked together on the east side of the street a hundred feet north of the plaza).
The little plaza in the foreground is formed by the junction of the original Houston Street (from the Bowery to this point), the former Hammersley Street (at the left), which in 1858 was made part of Houston Street, and Bedford Street, which on the analogy of Bleecker Street, might have been absorbed by Houston had it not been for Hammersley Street. At the right, Hancock Street, a one-block street now being absorbed by Sixth Avenue Extension, comes into the plaza at right angles to Houston Street. At the left of View No. 2, may be seen the billboards at the right angle junction of Congress (originally Smith) Street and Houston Street.
October 11, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
Another view with the camera more to the west.
October 11, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, from the ground, from and including Sixth Avenue, three and a half years later.
February 20, 1932.
P.L. Sperr.

724514f-a.text:
West Houston Street, north side, (in foreground not shown) between Sixth Ave. Extension (left) and MacDougal (right) Streets, showing, under construction, a portion of the Eighth Ave. Subway, making a sharp bend from West Houston Street, and proceeding northward, under the new Sixth Ave. Extension. Also shown (left) are the rears of 6-story houses, Nos. 13 to 1 Hancock Street. (now 260 to 270 Sixth Ave). On the right appears a view northward on the
east side of MacDougal Street.
June 15, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

724516f-a.text:
195 West Houston Street (originally 30 Hammersley Street), south side, west of Sixth Avenue (former Congress Street). The brick facing on this frame house may have been as recent as 1922.

1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 94.
Neg # 2447
